0b1bf0fac7e14178e9aa923f89d3bf70375acacf.commit.message:
Update the comments in PropertyUtils so that the FIXME notes about things that
do not support DynaBeans are visible in the JavaDocs, not just the sources.

Add a "package.html" file for the o.a.c.beanutils.converters package.

112cf25708274d71ae55e0e6b78d4c31731527b1.commit.message:
Fix BeanUtils.populate() so that you can use mapped property selectors in
the keys of the map.  Added JUnit tests to verify correct operation for both
standard JavaBeans and DynaBeans.

Patch Submitted By:  Miguel Zapaton <commonslist at sslmail.de>

Thanks for the patch!

Make BeanUtils.populate() ignore unmatched property names in *all*
circumstances, not just some of them.  :-(.

f4e24f0b19dbbb002036fce86b8eec1e3ab0ad75.commit.message:
Restore the previous BeanUtils.populate() behavior of simply ignoring property
names in the map that do not exist.  Otherwise, Struts based apps (which use
this to populate the form bean) will have lots of problems.

b774009f79cbb25702a2d3455ab2c07992372a07.commit.message:
Refactor and fix BeanUtils.populate() so that it will correctly set
nested properties on DynaBeans.  I did not use the proposed patch (but
thanks anyway!) for two reasons:

- It included "return" statements inside the loop that would have
  stopped processing all of the properties in the Map

- It only supported one level of nesting (which was also true of the
  old code for standard JavaBeans).

Now, you can have an arbitrarily deep set of nested beans, and these nested
beans can be any combination of DynaBean and standard JavaBean types.

Added test cases for setting nested properties via BeanUtils.populate(), and
verified that all previous test cases continue to work.

PR: Bugzilla #7521
Submitted by:	Anil Mandava <amandava at yahoo.com>

c2875414b9715e9a726f6ca0387a562ec6784dea.commit.message:
Fixed bug 7740. Klaasjan Brand supplied a patch which was very helpful in locating the problem but a slightly different patch was committed mainly for stylistic reasons. Also added extra tests covering the cause of failure. Also corrected another coding mistake (again mea culpa) in the same passage of code.
